newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan shares seen boosted by Bhutto's sacking.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan shares seen boosted by Bhutto's sacking.

text.p: Pakistani President Farooq Leghari's decision to sack Benazir Bhutto's government will bolster investor confidence and could give a short-term boost to the stock market, brokers said on Tuesday.
"The investors had a perception about Benazir that she was anti-business," Kalim Aziz, research head at Baring Securities, told Reuters. "True or not, they will initially react positively."
Aziz predicted the Karachi bourse, where shares jumped 2.80 percent on Monday, would extend its gains when it reopened on Wednesday. The bourse was closed on Tuesday due to a religious holiday.
He cited an expectation that the political and economic climate would clear with Bhutto's dismissal. Leghari accused Bhutto's government of corruption and nepotism.

On Monday, the Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) 100-share index rose 40.81 points to end at 1,499.97. Shares soared amid blue chip buying powered by a rise in synthetic fibre prices and some favourable corporate results.
A European diplomat said international reaction was likely to be muted.
"For Western governments, the attitude will probably be that any change of government that happens constitutionally and peacefully is not really their business," he said.
An International Monetary Fund official said a visiting IMF team would pursue talks with the new government on reactivating a $600 million standby loan.

The military, which has ruled Pakistan for 24 of the 49 years since independence, has kept a low profile. But political observers said Leghari could not have acted without securing the approval and cooperation of the generals.
Mohammad Yaseen, treasury head at ANB Amro Bank, said an end to tension between Bhutto and Leghari could lift a cloud of uncertainty from the bourse.
"If the caretakers can initiate a fair accountability process, it could really help to restore investor confidence in the country in the long run," Yaseen said.
Dealer Ali Asghar of Fortune Securities said most investors blamed Bhutto for mismanagement of the economy and held her responsible for the political chaos.
"The market will take the news as positive, as for them the political and economic mess was of the making of Benazir Bhutto," Asghar said.
But Aziz said the market could fall off amid uncertainty ahead of the general elections, which have been called for February 3.
"The market will act nervously if it does not become clear who stands the chance to win the next elections," he said.
